The [] tells the compiler
b
we have a lambda (and it will contain how we capture variables, either by value or by reference)
Besides the lambda input parameters, we can also access state in outer scopes from within the lambda body by specifying variable names within the square brackets of the lambda declaration.
Capturing by value
b
makes a copy of the variable, storing the copy in the lambda
Capturing by reference
b
stores a reference to the variable, so the lambda sees updates to the variable
By default
b
, lambdas treat all captured values as
const
b
or
const &
b
Adding the "mutable" keyword
b
gets rid of the const-ness of the capture, allowing us to modify what was captured
Lambdas play nicely with templates. You can use lambdas as template parameters to pass around function-like objects without having to write out a messy function type.
An
Ivalue
b
is something with an identity that isn't at end of life
A
prvalue
b
is something without identity that is at end of life - a "pure" rvalue. rvalue is a value that doesn't have a memory address.
An
xvalue
b
is something in between - an "expiring" value
The category of rvalues (which now means
xvalues
b
and
prvalues
b
) contain things that are at end-of-life. We'll see what this means when we talk about move
Let's go back to our
identity-lifetime picture
b
, but let's call things about to expire "able to be moved from".
An
lvalue
b
reference will only accept lvalues. An
rvalue
b
reference will only accept
rvalues
b
(which are
xvalues
b
or
prvalues
b
). This lets us write different functions depending on what type of reference we use.
For a specific type T, we can have two different kinds of references
T & will only bind to Ivalues
b
: can't have
int & x = 5;
b
nor
int & x = add(2,2);
b
T && will only bind to rvalues
b
: with
int x = 5,
b
both
xvalues
b
and
prvalues
b
will be taken by the move operators (if they exist)
Ivalues
b
will be taken by the copy operators (Ivalue reference (&) takes Ivalues)
I’ve used
T &&
b
to mean rvalue reference to
T
b
. If
T
b
is an actual specific type, this is true. If it is a template parameter,
b
is a universal reference.

b
in certain places in templates,
b

b
: This is an unfortunate syntax choice in C++ that you have to be mindful of when writing templated code or using the auto keyword. It's why you see a lot of "
std::foward
b
" calls in templated functions.
In templates with
universal reference
b

std::forward

Ivalue-

RAII is all about writing safe code. You don't have to add unlock statements on every error path, for example; the destructor will do it for you. We're guaranteed the destructor will get called when an object goes out of scope.
We can leverage an object's lifecycle so that the object will clean up after itself when it's destructed/destroyed.

A virtual function is a member function which is declared within a base class and is re-defined (overridden) by a derived class. When you refer to a derived class object using a pointer or a reference to the base class, you can call a virtual function for that object and execute the derived class’s version of the function.
The derived class can either
fully replace
b
(“override”) the base class member function, or the derived class can
partially replace
b
(“augment”) the base class member function. The latter is accomplished by having the derived class member function call the base class member function, if desired.
When you have a pointer to an object, the object may actually be of a class that is derived from the class of the pointer (e.g., a
Vehicle*
c
that is actually pointing to a
Car
c
object; this is called “polymorphism”). Thus there are two types: the
static
b
i
type of the pointer (
Vehicle
c
, in this case), and the
dynamic
b
i
type of the pointed-to object (
Car
c
, in this case).
Static typing
i
b
means that the legality of a member function invocation is checked at the earliest possible moment: by the compiler at compile time.
The compiler uses the static type of the pointer to determine whether the member function invocation is legal
b
. If the type of the pointer can handle the member function, certainly the pointed-to object can handle it as well. E.g., if
Vehicle
c
has a certain member function, certainly
Car
c
also has that member function since
Car
c
is a kind-of
Vehicle
c
Dynamic binding
i
b
means that the address of the code in a member function invocation is determined at the last possible moment: based on the dynamic type of the object at run time. It is called “
dynamic binding
b
” because the binding to the code that actually gets called is accomplished dynamically (at run time). Dynamic binding is a result of
virtual
c
functions.
A pure virtual function is a function that must be overridden in a derived class and need not be defined. A virtual function is declared to be “pure” using the curious
c
syntax.
Abstract classes are immensely useful for defining interfaces. In fact, a class with no data and where all functions are pure virtual functions is often called an interface.
You can provide a definition for a pure virtual function as:
Base::f3() {

The compiler is allowed to make one implicit conversion to resolve the parameters to a function. What this means is that the compiler can use constructors callable with a
single parameter
b
to convert from one type to another in order to get the right type for a parameter.
In this example, the argument is not a
Foo
c
object, but an
int
c
. However, there exists a constructor for
Foo
c
that takes an
int
c
so this constructor can be used to convert the parameter to the correct type. Therefore,
DoBar
c
will implicit call
Foo(42)
c
. To avoid this, add
explicit
c
before Foo constructor.
one interesting this is that, if the Foo has two constructors as below:

explicit Foo (int foo) : m_foo (foo) {cout<<"call construct 1"<<endl;}
Foo(float foo) : m_foo (0) {cout<<"call construct 2"<<endl;}
the DoBar will implicitly call construct 2. So it is important to make sure if all constructors will be called implicitly.
The difference is that struct member fields and functions are public by default, whereas for classes they are private by default

Adding

impl

forces a re-compile of only the
impl

A template's parameters can be a list of type parameters or non-type parameters. Non-type parameters can be numeric types, enum types, pointer types, etc.
Variadic templates are usually written with recursion. Define a behavior for one argument, and then peel off one argument at a time and recurse.
In the example, sum(1,2,3,4) will lead to 1 + sum(2,3,4), which will lead to 1 + 2 + sum(3,4), which will lead to 1 + 2 + 3 + sum(4), which will finally give us 1 + 2 + 3 + 4.
Passing a function
b
to call as a template parameter lets you put a bunch of generic work in one place rather than in each function you'll be calling.
Rather than performing the recursion at run time, this
will happen at compile time
b
Downside
b
: Compiled code size grows (in this case, the compiler has to generate 5 different functions to call) (However, with some optimizations, most compilers would replace the function call "
factorial<4U>()
b

b
casts
x
b
to an xvalue that can then be bound to rvalue refs (&&)

When the pointer variable point to a const value
When the const pointer variable point to the value
When const pointer pointing to a const variable
Pass const-argument value to a non-const parameter of a function cause error
const object can only invoke const function
const function cannot change a member variable of the class
In the age of C++11, however, it is strongly advised to return values as non-const so that you can take full advantage of rvalue references, which only make sense on non-constant rvalues.
